3. The first permanent theatre in Rome was the theatre

ol Pompey, finished in 55 ae. In the time oi Plautus a temporary wooden stage was erected for each performance, and the audience stood in front ol it or sat upon seats ol their own providing. From the back wall ol the stage pro jected the ironts oi three houseS, and there were entrances at the right and left sides of the stage. lls will be explained below, the plays were reproductions ol Greek comedies and the actors wore Greek dress, but masks were not used. Where the plot of the play required that two characters should re- semble each other in appearance, as in the Amphitruo and the Menaechmi, the necessary likeness was produced by wigs and paints, in the use oi which the Romans were skiliul. . 4. As there was no change ol scene, there was no neces· sity lor a break in the action, though in afew plays there were certainly briei musical interludes. Considerable parts of the plays were given with musical accompaniment, ren· dered upon the tibz'a by a player who stood upon the stage. The portions oi the comedy which are written in trochaic septenarii (Capi. 2 51-360, 385-496, Trz'n. 301-391, 602—728, etc.) were declaimed or chanted while the tibicen played a slight accompaniment in the same measure. In other scenes - the verse varied, often from line to line, the musical accom- paniment was more prominent, and the action more nearly resembled a dance. As this required somewhat violent exertion, the lines were sometimes sung, not by the actor himsell, but by a special cantor, while the actor confined himself to giving the appropriate gestures and motions. The musical parts oi the play were called cantica. The parts to be spoken without music, the dz'uerbzia, were written in iambic senarii. In the Trinummus the ratio ol diuerbia to cantica is about 2 : 5, in the Captivi about 1 : 3.
